text: Patient: Right. Doctor: The actual treatment, also, like I said, on the study, there’s a two out of three chance that you will get the treatment. Okay? Uh, A___? I’ll tell S___ to come in. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: But, uh, you know, I think it is a chance, and none of us have any control over what you get. But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now. Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. text: Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and- Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help.

text: Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point. Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

text: Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
